element.name: Must have/follow procedures and controls to prevent, detect and correct security issues in IT systems
element.documentation:
See also :
https://wiki.windmill.local/display/ITSec/Control+07+-+Security+Event+Monitoring
https://wiki.windmill.local/display/ITSec/Control+15+-+Ensure+effective+access+management+mechanisms+are+in+place+to+prevent+excessive+and+toxic+combinations+of+users+entitlements
5.6.1 Vulnerability scanning and mitigation
1. Detection and correction controls must be implemented to protect against known vulnerabilities by checking for corresponding new security updates.
Detail is described in the Vulnerability Scanning and Mitigation standard.
5.6.2 Data Loss Prevention
1. Prevention, detection and correction controls must be implemented to protect data from being lost or leaked (in accordance with the data classification).
Detail is described in the Data Loss Prevention Standard.
5.6.3 IT Network
1. All ABN AMRO controlled IT networks must have an owner who is accountable for the security and availability of the network infrastructure. The collection of networks that fall under the accountability of one owner is referred to as an Administrative Domain. Owners are part of a local IT organisation. The Administrative Domains may be connected using Zone Interconnects (see rule 6).
2. The CTO is accountable for the overarching network and maintains a list of the Administrative Domains and the associated owners. This owner is also responsible for network functions that are implemented in multiple Administrative Domains and that need to be centrally managed and maintained.
3. The CISO is accountable for the network security and operations relating to the use of the network by applications.
4. Access to and use of network devices must be properly protected in line with the ABN AMRO policies and standards and documented in designs.
5. Only ABN AMRO Controlled Devices may be connected to the network. The network owner is accountable for implementation of the controls in the IT network. The device owners are responsible for compliance of the device. Unauthorised devices can be connected to a Security Zone that is isolated from the ABN AMRO network, like WiFi networks for guests.
6. Networks compartmentalisation must be implemented to mitigate the impact of possible attacks. All systems within a Network Security Zone may communicate with each other in line with the FSA Network Security Framework. Inbound and outbound traffic must be controlled by a Zone Interconnect Function. The main purpose of the Zone Interconnect Function is to enable connectivity and security controls between Network Security Zones. It must provide monitoring capabilities and must allow traffic where authorised. A detailed description of these functions can be found in the FSA Network Security Framework14.
7. Pre-defined patterns of filtering rules and/or Network Security Zones that are generated in an automated way, must be used.
8. Traffic traversing the boundary between an ABN AMRO controlled network and any other network must pass the Network Secure Perimeter. Changes must be validated by Global Perimeter Security process. When traversing the Network Secure Perimeter both filtering of traffic and session termination are mandatory. The basic set of security controls that need to be applied are described in the Standard for Network Secure Perimeter15.
9. The Standard for Network Secure Perimeter must only allow approved and accepted connectivity. All other channels must be denied by default. The basic set of security controls that need to be applied are described in the Standard for Network Secure Perimeter16. Business services (external connectivity) traversing the perimeter must only be allowed when there is a clear and documented business need and in a controlled manner (without exposing the inner network).
5.6.4 Network Security
Network Security provides an extra layer of protection for the Bank’s data communications. Individuals and systems are not allowed to access data unless specifically permitted (default deny access). This helps the Bank achieve more granular control of its data and strengthens the layered approach to Information security. The FSA Network Security Framework and the Standard for Network Secure perimeter work in tandem to guide teams on the safest ways to make their data available to only authorised parties across the Bank’s networks, clouds and the Internet. Additional requirements on how to secure network infrastructure across the hybrid clouds are described in the Network Security standard.
5.6.5 Endpoint protection
1. Prevention, detection and correction controls must be implemented to protect endpoints and entry points including servers, workstations and mobile devices.
2. Endpoints must be evaluated to determine whether they meet the security standards defined by the Bank before they are granted access to the corporate network.
3. Prevention, detection and correction controls must be implemented to protect against malicious software (Malware). Malware protection requirements are further detailed in the Malware Protection Standard.
4. IT assets and IT systems must be installed and configured using defined and agreed security hardening baselines before they are allowed access to the corporate network. Additional requirements are described in the System Hardening standard.
5.6.6 E-mail enabled applications
1. Controls must be in place to ensure the security of email and mail-enabled applications commensurate to the CIA rating of its content.
Detail is described in the E-mail and Calendaring standard.
5.6.7 Confidentiality and integrity check mechanisms
1. Prevention, detection and correction controls must be implemented to safeguard the confidentiality and integrity of data in storage and data in transit (software, firmware and data).
Refer to the Data Governance Policy (101-23-43) for more information.

element.name: Follow AAB requirements for IT Development and IT Change
element.documentation:
IT Development and IT Change
This section covers the management of IT development, IT change, IT architecture and patch – and vulnerability management.
6.1 Security requirements for IT development and acquisition
This section of the policy prescribes the security requirements that must be followed when developing, acquiring or maintaining IT assets or IT systems. Development and acquisition are critical stages to implement security measures in order to protect the confidentiality, integrity and availability of IT assets and IT systems.
6.1.1 Development lifecycle
1. The Bank must apply a formalised process for the development, acquisition and maintenance of information systems, using a risk based approach.
6.1.1.1 Security requirements The functional and non-functional requirements, including information security requirements, must be clearly defined and approved by the relevant business management. Appropriate security controls must be defined and included in the system architecture and design. The controls must be effective in preventing unintentional alteration and intentional manipulation of IT systems during development. Proper data input validation before data handling and/or processing is a key requirements for every IT asset.
6.1.1.2 Design The design of IT systems and IT assets must be in line with the IT architecture (refer to the Architecture Policy (108-40-00)), including functional and non-functional security requirements concerning people, process and technology.
6.1.1.3 Development During development, ABN AMRO's security standards must be followed. Security standards include architecture standards and coding standards for programming languages. Coding standards for programming languages must at least include security requirements related to input & output validation, the handling of access control, use of cryptographic algorithms, logging and exception handling. Developers must be skilled and experienced with security standards and best practices. The developers must be trained and/or certified for secure coding best practices. During development, developers must produce documentation that describe coded functionalities and that is sufficient to facilitate maintenance, trouble shooting and changes or enhancements.
6.1.1.4 Acquisition The formal acquisition process must include an information security assessment to determine whether the requirements of this policy are met by the IT system or IT asset prior to purchasing. In case they are not met mitigating controls must be identified and implemented.
6.1.1.5 Testing
IT testing must comply with the minimum requirements set out in this paragraph.
A methodology must be in place for testing and approval of IT systems prior to their first use. This methodology must be proportional to the criticality of the system. The testing must ensure that new IT systems perform as intended. Test environments must be used that adequately reflect the production environment. IT systems, IT services and information security measures must be tested to identify potential security weaknesses, violations and incidents. Confidentiality highly sensitive data (C=1) must not be placed in a test environment. A code quality check must be performed on program code. Special attention must be given to parts of the source code that:
a. Processes secret security codes like passwords, cryptographic keys, and PIN codes.
b. Manages access to critical system functions.
c. Has the ability to bypass overall security mechanisms, for example self-programmed or modifications to supervisor calls. If the Bank does not have access to the source code, a penetration test must be performed. All systems delivered by ABN AMRO to customers must be thoroughly checked for harmful and insecure code using appropriate tools and procedures.
6.1.2 Development environment Development, test and acceptance environments must be separated from production environments to ensure adequate segregation of duties and to reduce the risk of unauthorised access or changes to production systems and data. The adequacy of the environment separation must be assessed via an information security assessment. Access to production data must be restricted to authorised users. To protect the integrity of source codes:
a. Source libraries must be securely stored.
b. Access control to program source code must be implemented and associated items must be logged to maintain an audit trail. The development, implementation, operation and configuration of the IT systems must be traceable. The documentation of the IT system must contain at least user documentation, technical system documentation and operating procedures.
6.1.3 End User Developed Applications (EUDAs)
Non-IT managed IT assets developed and/or managed by end-users (EUDAs18) have the potential to become critical elements of business processes and can impose a security, privacy, data ownership, availability and continuity risk if they are not governed by IT oversight and relevant IT management practices. Minimum requirements as it relates to EUDAs are set out in this paragraph. Refer to the EUDA standard for additional requirements.
1. In principle the creation and use of EUDAs should be avoided and IT Development and IT Change must be conducted in accordance with the guidance as detailed throughout the remainder of this Chapter 6.
2. Where it is deemed that the use of a EUDA in a business process is unavoidable, the Bank must assess, in accordance with the principle of risk-based19 management (see section 2 and 4.5.2), whether the EUDA is material and qualifies for onboarding. In this context, onboarding means that the material EUDA will become subject to the requirements and controls as specified in this policy. Notably this includes, formal registration in OAR (see the requirements on the identification, rating, registration of IT assets of section 4.4), access management and recertification (see Chapter 0), and the full development lifecycle, referencing system development and documentation (see 6.1.1).
3. The Bank must document its process with respect to the identification, onboarding and resolution of material EUDAs. In this respect:
a. The risk-based approach as translated into the ‘EUDA materiality criteria’ is further detailed in the EUDA Standard.
b. In derogation from the requirement as listed in 4.4.2(1), this EUDA materiality criteria must first be applied to test whether a EUDA is in fact material, and will subsequently only be onboarded where this is the case. Any EUDA that has previously been classified as a highly sensitive (or higher) information/ IT asset (see section 4.4.3) will by default be captured by the existing requirements and controls as specified throughout this policy.
6.1.4 Open source software
Open source software is a term used in the information and communications technology industry, but it can mean different things to different people. ABN AMRO follows the definition from the Open Source Initiative (OSI)20.
The key requirements for the use of open source software is set out below. For detailed requirements, refer to the Open Source Software standard.
1. To ensure adherence to the license & intellectual property ownership and fitness for purpose when using open source software, the following requirements apply.
a. Open source software must comply with all ABN AMRO information security standards.
b. Open source software must be handled within the standard development, testing, and deployment procedures as if it were third-party vendor software or in-house developed code.
c. The source (and method) from which the open source software is obtained must not expose ABN AMRO to unacceptable risks.
d. The security and license status of software must be validated throughout the lifecycle.
2. To prevent accidental disclosure of confidential information when publishing open source software, the following additional requirements apply.
a. Approval from the Open Source Review Board (OSRB) is required.
b. The software needs to be released under a suitable license. It is recommended to follow existing guidelines.
c. The Intellectual Property (IP) risk needs to be mitigated by having an auditable record of ownership.
6.2 IT change management
The IT Service Support standard contains the rules that apply to the implementation of the Bank’s IT change management process.
1. Formal and standard change management processes must be in place to ensure that all changes to IT assets and IT systems are recorded, tested, assessed, approved, implemented and verified in a controlled manner. The procedures must make provision for changes during emergencies ('emergency changes’), including roll-back of changes.
2. It must be determined whether changes in the existing operational environment influence the existing security measures or require the adoption of additional measures to mitigate the risks involved.
6.3 Patch management
1. IT assets and IT systems, including the software and firmware provided by the Bank to its internal and external users, must be kept up to date by deploying security patches according to their priority level. For detailed requirements see the Patch Management Standard.
6.4 Lifecycle management
1. The Bank must monitor and manage the life cycles of configuration items (applications, platforms and hardware), to ensure that they continue to meet and support risk management and operational requirements. The Lifecycle Management standard set out the detailed requirements associated with the lifecycle management of applications, platforms and hardware.
2. All IT assets and IT systems in use by the Bank must have a plan to stay in the preferred lifecycle support state (“regular support”).
3. Triggers to remain in the regular support state must be identified and activated in time.

element.name: Is monitored to identify potential security weaknesses, violations and incidents
element.documentation:
5.7.2 Security logging and monitoring
The Bank must establish and implement capabilities to detect anomalous activities that may impact its information security and to respond to these events appropriately. The Information Security Monitoring standard sets out the detailed requirements for security logging and monitoring. For physical security logging and monitoring refer to section 5.4.
Security logging and monitoring must take place continuously and must include appropriate and effective detection and reporting of physical intrusion or logical intrusion as well as breaches of confidentiality, integrity and availability of IT assets, IT systems and IT Services. The continuous monitoring and detection processes must cover at least:
a. Relevant internal and external factors, including business and IT administrative functions.
b. Transactions to detect misuse of access by third parties or other entities and internal misuse of access.
c. Potential internal and external threats. Security threats that could materially affect the Bank’s ability to provide services must be actively monitored. This includes monitoring the security risks in technological developments, and detective measures to identify possible information leakages, malicious code and other security threats. The security logs must be useful to understand the nature of operational or security incidents, to identify trends and to support the Bank’s investigations.

element.name: Must have processes in place for IT Availability and Continuity
element.documentation:
7.1 IT operations management The performance of IT operations must be aligned to business requirements. The Bank must maintain and improve, when possible, efficiency of their IT operations, including but not limited to the need to consider how to minimise potential errors arising from the execution of manual tasks. Logging and monitoring procedures must be in place for critical IT operations to allow the detection, analysis and correction of errors. The Bank must implement performance and capacity planning processes to prevent, detect and respond to important performance issues of IT systems and IT capacity shortages in a timely manner.
7.1.1 Configuration management
The Service Support Standard sets out the detailed requirements related to configuration management.
All configuration items must have an owner. The Bank must maintain a complete, accurate and up-to-date inventory of its configuration items. The inventory must store the configuration of its items and the links and interdependencies between the different configuration items to enable a proper configuration and change management process, and to help in the response to security and operational incidents, including cyber-attacks. The inventory must be centralised and must be sufficiently detailed to enable the prompt identification of configuration items, its location, security classification and ownership.
7.2 IT incident and problem management
To monitor and log operational and information security incidents, and to enable the Bank to continue, in a timely manner, critical business functions and processes when disruptions occur, the Bank maintains incident and problem management processes. For detailed requirements on incident and problem management refer to the Service Support Standard.
1. Criteria and thresholds must be determined to classify events as operational or security incidents.
2. Early warning indicators must be set to enable early detection of incidents.
7.2.1 IT incident management
An incident management process must be in place to minimise the impact of incidents and to enable the timely resolution of incidents.
1. Incident response processes must mitigate the impacts that are related to incidents and ensure that the service becomes operational and secure in accordance with the agreed service level.
2. The process to identify, track, log, categorise and classify incidents must be based on business criticality.
3. The process must allow for different types of incident scenarios (for example, errors, malfunctioning and cyber-attacks).
7.2.2 IT problem management
A problem management process must be in place to minimise the negative effect on business as a result of recurring incidents or incidents that are likely to occur in IT assets, IT system or IT services.
1. Problem management must be focused on identifying, analysing and solving the root causes behind incidents. Operational and information security incidents likely to affect the Bank and that have been identified or have occurred within or outside the Bank must be analysed. Key lessons learned from these analyses must be considered and, where necessary, must lead to a permanent fix or mitigation of the impact of the incident.
7.2.3 Internal and external communication of incidents
1. IT incidents must be reported to the local helpdesk.
2. Information security incidents must be reported internally in terms of the requirements of the Reporting and Prevention of Security Incidents and Compliance Breaches Policy (108-75-08). This includes:
a. Information security incidents with a potential criminal intent and compliance breaches.
b. Information security incidents concerning breaches of confidential information and incidents that are publicly exposed.
c. Information security incidents concerning a potential personal data breach.
d. Information security incidents and weaknesses without (suspected) criminal intent.
3. Other information security incidents and weaknesses (not mentioned in this point 1) must be reported to the line manager who must immediately take action or advise on follow-up.
4. All information related to the occurred and reported information security incidents or reported weaknesses must be documented, retained and be available.
5. Appropriate management reporting of information security incidents must be available to monitor the quality of the information security incident management process.
6. Specific external communication plans must be established for incidents to critical business functions and processes in order to:
a. Collaborate with relevant stakeholders to effectively respond to and recover from the incident.
b. Provide timely information to external parties (for example, customers, other market participants, the supervisory authority) as appropriate and in line with applicable regulation.
c. Report cyber incidents to the supervisory authority.
7.3 IT continuity
This section describes the IT continuity requirements for IT assets, IT systems and IT services. For business continuity requirements, including Business Impact Analysis (BIA) and the determination of a Recovery Time Objective (RTO) and Recovery Point Objective (RPO), refer to the Business Continuity Management Policy (102-15-10). For crisis management and communication, refer to the Crisis Management Policy (102-15-20).
7.3.1 IT continuity design
1. The IT architecture must encompass relevant continuity aspects, such as availability and recoverability, in such a way that all defined recovery requirements can be met. When the architecture requires specific continuity considerations and / or testing requirements, these must be documented and provided to the relevant entities.
2. For IT continuity purposes, the criticality of IT assets and IT systems is determined by both its Availability rating and Recovery Time Objective (RTO).
a. Continuity critical IT assets and IT systems are those that have an Availability rating of highly sensitive (A=1) and an RTO < 2 hours.
b. Continuity highly sensitive IT assets and IT systems are those that have an Availability rating of highly sensitive (A=1) and an RTO 2-4 hours.
c. Continuity sensitive IT assets and IT systems are those that have an Availability rating of sensitive (A=2) and an RTO 4-24 hours.
d. Continuity non- sensitive IT assets and IT systems are those that have an Availability rating of non- sensitive (A=3) and an RTO > 24 hours.
3. IT assets, IT systems and IT services must be designed in line with the Business Impact Analysis (BIA) outcome such as redundancy of critical components to prevent disruptions caused by events impacting those components. They must be able to work (run) on the required equipment during “Business as Usual” as well as switch to the required recovery solutions within the required timeframe and other relevant business requirements.
7.3.2 IT continuity planning IT continuity plans must be put in place to ensure that the Bank can react appropriately to potential failure scenarios and to ensure that the Bank is able to recover the operations of business activities after disruptions within the agreed recovery objectives (including RTO and RPO). IT continuity plans must be set up and documented by management responsible for service management and delivery. The IT asset owner remains accountable and must provide the appropriate RTO and RPO values for their asset. The IT continuity plans must specifically consider risks that could adversely impact IT assets, IT systems and IT services. The plans must support objectives to protect and, if necessary, re-establish the confidentiality, integrity and availability of business functions, IT processes, IT assets, IT systems and IT services. The plans must be aligned with relevant internal and external stakeholders.
In terms of the IT continuity plan, it must be possible to re-establish IT assets, IT systems and IT services according to their specified RTO and RPO. In cases of severe business disruption that trigger multiple IT continuity plans, IT continuity actions must be prioritised, using a risk-based approach. A range of different scenarios must be considered in the IT continuity planning, including extreme but plausible scenarios to which the Bank might be exposed (including a cyber-attack scenario). The IT continuity plan must contain a description of how the continuity of IT assets, IT systems, IT services, as well as information security, will be ensured under the scenarios.
7.3.3 IT disaster recovery
1. Based on the outcome of BIAs and plausible scenarios, IT disaster recovery plans (also named IT Service Recovery Plans) must be developed. These plans state the activation triggers and what actions will be taken to ensure the availability, continuity and recovery of, at a minimum, critical IT assets, IT systems and IT services. The IT disaster recovery plans must aim to meet the recovery objectives that have been set.
2. The IT disaster recovery plans should consider both short-term and long-term recovery options. Minimal requirements for these plans are:
a. Focus on the recovery of the operations of critical business functions, IT processes, IT assets, IT systems, IT services and their interdependencies to avoid adverse effects on the functioning of the Bank and on the financial system.
b. Documented and available to the business and support units and readily accessible in the event of an emergency.
c. Updated in line with lessons learned from incidents, tests, new risks identified and threats, and changed recovery objectives and priorities.
d. Consider alternative options where recovery may not be feasible in the short term because of costs, risks, logistics or unforeseen circumstances.
e. Inclusion of continuity measures to mitigate failures of third party providers, which are of key importance for the Bank’s IT assets, IT systems and IT service continuity (refer also to the Third Party & Outsourcing Risk Policy (108-70-20)).
7.3.4 Testing of plans
1. The owner of the IT asset, IT system or IT service is accountable for IT disaster recovery testing.
2. IT disaster recovery plans related to critical business functions and associated IT processes, IT assets, IT systems, IT services and their interdependencies (including those provided by third parties) must be tested when significant change are made to the plan, and at least annually.
3. Disaster recovery plans must be tested when significant changes are made to the plan, and according to the following minimum frequency:
a. RTO 0-2 hours: at least every year (critical).
b. RTO 2-4 hours: at least every 2 years (highly sensitive).
c. RTO 4-24 hours: at least once (sensitive).
d. RTO >24 hours: at least once (non-sensitive).
4. IT disaster recovery plans must be updated at a frequency that is related to their criticality, based on available testing results, current threat intelligence and lessons learned from previous events. Any changes in recovery objectives (including RTOs and RPOs), business functions, IT processes, IT assets, IT systems or IT services must also be considered in the review of the plans.
5. Through testing of IT disaster recovery plans the Bank must be able to demonstrate that it is able to sustain the viability of business functions until critical operations are re-established. In particular they should:
a. Include testing of an adequate set of extreme but plausible scenarios.
b. Verify the ability of staff and contractors, IT assets, IT systems and IT services to respond adequately to the extreme but plausible scenarios.
c. Include the switch-over of critical business functions, IT processes, IT assets, IT systems, IT services to the disaster recovery environment and demonstrating that IT processes can run in this way for a sufficiently representative period of time and that normal functioning can be restored afterwards.
d. Include testing of services provided by third parties.
e. Be designed to challenge the assumptions on which IT disaster recovery plans rest, including governance arrangements and crisis communication plans.
6. Test results must be documented and identified deficiencies resulting from the tests must be analysed, addressed and reported depending on severity of the deficiency (refer to the Business Continuity Management Policy for reporting requirements).
7.3.5 Back-up and restore
This paragraph describes the minimum requirements for the back-up and recovery of data and IT systems. For further detail, refer to the Back-up and Restore standard.
1. Backup and restore procedures must be defined and implemented for data and IT systems to ensure that they can be recovered as required.
2. The scope and frequency of back-ups must be in line with IT disaster recovery requirements and the CIA rating of the data and the IT systems.
3. Testing of the backup and restore procedures must be undertaken on a periodic basis.
4. Back-ups must be stored in a secure environment that are sufficiently remote from where the original data is processed and stored so that they are not exposed to the same physical risks.

element.name: Is regularly tested to evaluate the effectiveness of risk management strategies
element.documentation:
5.7.1 Security testing
The purpose of security testing is to validate the robustness and effectiveness of the information security measures that are implemented and to protect information assets against internal and external threats. For more detail refer to the Information Security review, analysis and testing standard.
Security testing must consider threats and vulnerabilities identified throughout the IT development lifecycle. Based on the security threats observed and the changes made, testing must be updated to incorporate scenarios of relevant and known potential attacks. The testing of security measures must:
a. Be performed periodically.
b. Be carried out by staff or external experts that possesses sufficient knowledge, skills and expertise in testing information security measures and who are not involved in the development of the information security measures.
c. Include vulnerability scans, penetration tests17 (including threat-led penetration testing where necessary and appropriate) and code review, commensurate with the level of risk identified with the business processes and systems. Tests of security measures on IT systems and IT assets must be repeated in line with the frequency prescribed in section 5.1. Tests of security measures must be conducted earlier if changes are made due to major operational or security incidents, or due to other changes to the threat environment. The results of security tests must be monitored and evaluated and used to update security measures accordingly and without undue delays in the case of highly sensitive IT assets or IT systems.

element.name: Is classified
element.documentation: The Asset owner is accountable for the appropriate execution of the information asset classification process and must approve the assigned ratings after verification by the data owner (108-49-21-002). • Verification by the data owner must ensure that the information asset classification is in line with value of the data that the information asset contains

element.name: Shared Information Assets have one overall business owner
element.documentation:
For shared information assets one owner must be appointed as overall business owner (108- 49-21-003). • Some information assets are used within more business processes or by multiple data
owners (shared usage). In that case there can be multiple business owners.

element.name: Future date and historical position views
Has one owner
element.documentation:
Every information asset must ultimately have one owner, who is accountable for the security of the information asset
.
Note: • For classification of information assets see the Information Risk Policy and the Standard for Asset Classification. • Within the bank information asset owners are assigned. These must fulfil its data ownership responsibilities related to information assets. IT must fulfil its technical responsibilities related to information assets that may include activities such as database administration, system development, etc. The Asset owner for applications is called Application Owner (AO). The Asset Owner for IT infrastructure components is called the IT Infrastructure Owner. In the
main bank, primarily the Product Owner is assigned the Application owner role. In countries and Subsidiaries, there can be exceptions on who will take the Application Owner role.
Requirements for assigning an Asset owner: align with line management, end users (documents), data- /process-/application ownership).

element.name: Must have logical access control
element.documentation:
This section defines the minimum requirements for identification, authentication, access and authorisation management of information assets. The asset owner is responsible for the implementation of identity and access measures and supervision of the implementation of the requirements as set out in this section.
5.2.1 Identification
Identification in the context of this section means assigning a digital identity4 to a person or thing. An identity and its characteristics will be registered as the digital identity when using information assets5.
Minimum requirements for identification that must be met:
1. Personal (human) and non-personal (non-human) identities must be uniquely identifiable, prior to granting access, thus ensuring all activities are traceable to a responsible person.
2. Every person or thing must therefore be assigned a unique digital identity.
3. A non-personal identity must be owned by a personal identity (human) or by a legal entity.
5.2.2 Authentication
Authentication is the process of verifying the presented identity (that is, someone or something is what it claims to be) prior to granting access, approving a transaction request (authorisation), signing a document or other product. The authentication factors are something the identity: • Knows (knowledge) • Has (possession) • Is (inherence)
Each authentication factor is assigned a trust level, which determines how much it contributes to the level of trust we can have in the authenticity of a claimed identity. An Authentication mean is an access control solution used to verify an identity, where combining multiple authentication factors increases the aggregate trust level of the authentication mean. In this respect:
1. An authentication mean may require one (or multiple) authentication factors to authenticate an identity. An authentication mean may only be assigned one of three trust levels:
a. Low
b. Substantial
c. High
2. Minimum requirements for authentication:
a. Identities must be authenticated prior to granting access to an information asset.
b. Identities must be authenticated using the minimum required authentication mean. That is, the presented authentication mean trust level (low, substantial or high) must at least correspond to the required risk level (low, medium, high) as determined by both the activity to be performed6 (business context dependent) and the information asset involved.
c. The required trust level for an authentication mean is determined as follows: • Firstly, by the confidentiality and/or integrity rating (CIA rating) of the information asset. • Secondly, with the activity to be performed (business context dependent) – refer to Table 1 below. • Access to information assets via a public network requires at least ‘substantial’ trust level, unless the data are publicly available. • Access to assets requested by things requires at least ‘substantial’ trust level.
5.2.3 Access Management and Authorisation
Access Management is the ability to manage and control the identity related access rights.
Authorisation is the ability to manage and control the event and context driven access.
5.2.3.1 Access Management
1. Access, must be granted, validated and reviewed by persons who:
a. Understand the responsibilities and tasks of the requestor, and
b. Understand the purpose of the work of the requestor, and
c. Understand the risk and classification of the requested access, and
d. Have the authority to approve the access, and
e. Is ABN AMRO personnel (with corporate ID).
2. Access must be based on approved Access Control Methodology (for example role based, rule based).
3. Access to information assets by employees or things must be allocated based on:
a. A least privilege basis: Identities may only be assigned privileges, for the time required, to perform their intended function, role or task. Revocation must be handled promptly (including during off-boarding).
b. A need-to-know principle: It must be necessary for the requestor to have access to the information asset and associated data.
c. An overview of, and restrictions on, available access rights taking into consideration: • Privileged access. • Segregation of duties: avoiding toxic combinations (for example, combination of access rights on the asset, or combination of assets, that gives users the ability to perform tasks that should never be controlled by a single user). • Non-personal accounts. • Clear guidelines with respect to data access to the asset and managed by the asset.
4. Privileged access, also applicable in case of elevation of privileges must be8.
a. Approved.
b. Granted on ‘time restricted basis’, and
c. Usage must be logged and monitored9.
5. Access given to customers must be based on:
d. Business requirements.
e. Informed and accepted use by the customer.
6. Periodic reviews regarding Identity & Access management are required for both employees and things. This review ensures the responsible person to validate the actual access rights, detecting over time harvested access rights or provided delegations10.
5.2.3.2 Authorisation
A Digital Identity will be authorised to perform tasks based on attributes, which are derived from financial products, customer contract, customer consent, geographical location and jurisdiction where customer and ABN AMRO operate.
1. Authorisation for these tasks are determined by business and relevant security and second line parties.
5.2.4 Implementation requirements as a function of Confidentiality or Integrity rating
1. Highly sensitive rated information assets, requiring access by employees or things, must have the following controls implemented:
a. Centralised identity and access solutions, accepted or approved by the capability owner (CISO). Identity and access management must be executed via specialised Identity & Access (I&A) tooling and by authorised staff at least at entity level (for example, subsidiaries, branches, representative offices and legal entities that are under its control (referred to as ''ABN AMRO'' or ''the Bank'')).
b. At all times it must be ensured that access rights can be reconciled (that is, access in the provisioning tool must be the same as access in the specific asset). For example, reconciliations between the provisioning tool and asset.
c. Automated execution: Access management must be executed using automated processes and tools.
d. Access based on Role Based Access Control (RBAC) and/or Attribute Based Access Control (ABAC)11.
e. Mandatory logging, including access rights. For access rights the Access Management process, Access SOLL, Access IST, and what the identity did within the application must be demonstrably stored
f. Single Sign On (SSO) meaning signing on once per user session12.
2. It is recommended that sensitive information assets apply the aforementioned practices listed in this point (1).
3. It is optional that non-sensitive information assets apply the aforementioned practices listed in this point (1).

element.name: If the client would be healthy the changes would not have taken place, the bank must make a consession. The chnage is in advantage of the client and is a disadvantage for the bank.
The contract is/must be changed or refinacing of the debt is necessay
Client has financial problems and can no longer (or it is expected on short term) fulfill his financial obligations towards the bank
1G: We standardise and globally align our IT development experience
1G: Development platforms offer rich functionality, enabling us to limit the ‘stack depth’ of DevOps and drive both IT Risk & Control and speed
1G: We globalise, standardise and harmonise IT landscape as much as beneficial
1G: We leverage existing capabilities and optimise agile & developer maturity of the organisation
BA03 : MAKE GLOBALLY SUITABLE SET UP
element.documentation:
Statement
The chosen set up of business and IT assets must be done in such a way that they are expandable towards other AAC countries.
Rationale
See GEAR Strategy.

element.name: BA05 : A SERVICE IS ONLY DEALT WITH ON ONE PLACE
element.documentation:
Statement
A client and or business services is only dealt with once on one place within a regional organisation unit with consistent architecture over the regions.
Rationale
AAC currently processes same services redundant. A set up whereas a service is dealt with on one place within the region will improve operationally efficiency and risk (competence centres) and will not cause data synchronisation issues.

element.name: BA02 : SINGLE MAINTENANCE OF STATIC DATA
element.documentation:
Statement
Static data attributes should only be maintained through a single (user) interface.
Rationale
AAC currently has, and will always have redundant data stores in their architecture. Maintenance of redundant data attributes through a single (user) interface will improve operationally efficiency as well as data quality, and thus business service quality.

element.name: BA01 : TRANSFORM INDEPENDENTLY
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must be able to transform independent of other business units
Rationale
The required rate of change differs between business units. If independent transformation is not taken in to account, the slowest business unit would define the rate of change for the whole organization

element.name: BA04 : OPERATE BUSINESS IN REAL-TIME
element.documentation:
Statement
All business functions with time criticality must be operated in real-time.
Rationale
See GEAR Strategy

element.name: IT08 : CLEAR SEPERATION OF SERVICES
element.documentation: Functionality should be implemented (grouped / separated) in line with the business service model.

element.name: IT04 : ONE FUNCTIONALITY, ONE SOLUTION
element.documentation: Functionalities will be implemented as one solution and be made available globally.

element.name: IT18 : IT DEDICATION FOR RISK MANAGEMENT
element.documentation:
IT Solutions for Risk Management will not share software components.
IT for risk will only share hardware devices with other business services when capacity can be guaranteed.

element.name: IT02 : DESIGN TO SCALE & HANDLE PEAKS
element.documentation: Solutions must be designed to scale and handle peaks of 2 times the average of the last 2 peaks that occurred in the last 18 months.

element.name: IT19 : APPLICATIONS CONTAIN JUST ENOUGH DATA
element.documentation: Business applications of a transaction processing nature should only hold the data objects that are required for an effective and efficient implementation/support of business processes.

element.name: IT07 : RATIONAL CHOICE BETWEEN REUSE, MAKE & BUY
element.documentation: Explicitly no dogmatic buy before build approach without regarding all aspects of the solution

element.name: IT01 : DON’T TOUCH OF THE SHELF PRODUCTS
element.documentation: Functionality in ‘of the shelf’ products (packages) may not be changed just for AAC. It can use an adapter to interface into AACB specific business logic but only if this was the intention of the vendor.

element.name: IT05 : MINE FIRST!
element.documentation: Mine the specifications from currently operational software components and use this as the basis for new development

element.name: IT06 : USE ENTERPRISE STANDARDS
element.documentation: AACB will build and/or deploy their information systems on enterprise standard technologies

element.name: IT09 : ARCHITECT SOLUTIONS IN AN EVENT DRIVEN WAY
element.documentation: During the architecting of solutions, the preference goes to using the ‘event driven architecture pattern’ over command and control patterns (i.e. request/reply, call stacks).

element.name: S09: Separation of Duties (resilient, secure)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by implementing 4 eye (or more) principle on sensitive business and IT processes.
Rationale
The reduce the risk surface of a sensitive role multiple eyes should be involved before a potentially high impact action can be executed. To reduce the likelihood of such an incident occurring multiple persons needed to approve or enabling the execution of an action provides additional security. Using multiple authorisation checks can prevent that the compromise of a single set of credentials immediately can result in high impact incidents.
Implications • Create processes for potentially high risk actions in such a way that multiple authorisations are needed to execute these. • Ensure that authorisations given to people in separate roles do not break separation of duties by declaring certain combinations as not permitted. • Monitor with appropriate tooling that authorisations given to users, files and directories, scripts, etc do not break separation of duty implicitly in a functional or technical fashion . (e.g. sudo statements in editable scripts on linux that are to broad or can be abused to inject commands in, monitor file systems for unwanted changes in file or directory rights, check config files for unauthorized modifications, etc)

element.name: S02: Kerckhoff’s Principle (Secure)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must not use security through obscurity based solutions.
Rationale
The security of a system must remain in effect even if all details of its implementation are known. This is called Kerckhoff’s principle , the open design principle. When for example generating tokens using hash functions or crypto libraries its use must remain secure even if the exact used functions are known. Security may not depend on the secrecy of the design of the used security solution.
Implications • Do not hardcode credentials in software or scripts • Do not encode usernames and passwords in URL’s which might leak into logs • Do not use self-designed crypto but only publicly vetted crypto solutions

element.name: S08: Fail Secure (secure)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface ensuring that actions during failure must default to a safe state.
Rationale
To reduce the risk surface we must ensure that components (e.g. applications, appliances, etc) function reliably when attacked. Components should default to a secure state by using principles like security by design (see elsewhere in this document) , secure by default (default settings of a product are secure out of the box) , secure in deployment (ensure proper security management functionality and arrange timely patches / updates for security issues , etc).
Implications • Default during attacks to an account (internal) / IP address (Internet) based lockout • Handle errors and exceptions instead of ignoring them and continuing • Do not leak technical error data to end user interfaces which could disclose sensitive information • Create debug functionality to insert information in logs to demonstrate compliance with secure failure • Create debug functionality to insert information in logs to provide intelligence to SIEM • Create anti use cases to test for secure failure

element.name: S04: Psychological Acceptability (Secure)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must design security mechanism aimed at maximizing usage, adoption and automatic application.
Rationale
Enforcing security mechanisms which tend to provoke users into insecure behaviour like writing passwords on paper notes is not effective. Accessibility of resources may not be impeded by difficult to use security mechanisms which will result in the structural triggering of insecure behaviour. This can also occur if many different passwords are placing a burden on users.
Implications • Use Single Sign On whenever possible • Use 2 factor authentication to enhance security on potentially high impact roles • For example use a bastion host with 2 factor for administrative access • Use a 2 factor mechanism that is sufficiently separated (virtual or physical) from the end point used • Do not implement systems which are clearly unsafe (no crypto) that use passwords used for privileged access. This will have serious legal consequences, see Non Repudiation. Furthermore it will have a demotivating effect on acceptance of security procedures. • Use Password managers to facilitate usage of high quality passwords or passphrases

element.name: S01: Economy of Mechanisms (Efficient)
element.documentation:
Statement
Reduce complexity to what is really needed to perform a function or service.
Rationale
Limiting the complexity of any solution or implementation reduces the risk surface by reducing the possible number of vulnerabilities.
Implications • Keep things as simple as needed but no simpler • Harden by eliminating functionality that is not needed • Remove unneeded authorisations of functional users • Remove unneeded functionality in source code • Disable unused functions in configurations • Remove unused software libraries, etc • Simpler implementations and designs reduce time and effort to fix vulnerabilities • Strive for operational ease of use: Single Sign on for example, implying re-use of solutions to reduce attack surface. • Since the knowledge of how to implement security architecture is very scarse a specialized security architect is needed. This person can create security architecture building blocks realizing a security reference architecture of secure solutions. • Since the knowledge of how to implement code in a secure fashion is very scarse a specialized secure software architect is needed. This person can create secure patterns and secure code snippets realizing a security reference library of secure implementations of crypto, authentication and authorisation functionality in various programming languages. This way such knowledge can be made available throughout the organisation.

element.name: S07: Least privilege (trustworthy, vigilance)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by limiting authorizations to what is needed to perform a role.
Rationale
To reduce the risk surface of a role, reduce the impact from a compromise of credentials, improve the monitoring visibility and comply with regulations.
Implications • Governance on authorisation design and access management is required. • Use modular programming as much as possible to compartmentalize where needed:
o During processing of data from untrusted sources (e.g. Internet)
o During program routines that use elevated privileges do not pass data from untrusted sources as input.
o Separate data handling of trusted versus untrusted data sources as a principle
o Prefer user space code over kernel space code • Authorizations of any kind (files, users, services, customer records) in any system or process must be designed in a minimalistic fashion to: • Reduce the risk of illegal data alterations (logs, transactions, etc) • Reduce risk surface of abuse • Reduce potential impact of abuse • Reduce chance of breaking separation of duty principle (See elsewhere in this list)

element.name: S10: Defense in Depth (secure)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by ensuring two defensive layers or more to mitigate each threat or risk.
Rationale
The reduce the risk surface we must take into account that a control might fail. To ensure the failure of a single control does not result in an immediate compromise a second or even third layer of defence is needed.
Implications • Never rely on a single protection mechanism • Combine prevention, detection and impact reduction to achieve a desired level of risk mitigation. • Assume breach when designing each security mechanism to identify a needed fallback mechanism each type of mitigating control • Be able to transfer sessions to honey pots

element.name: S05: Security by Design (secure, resilient, vigilance, trustworthy)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by stating security requirements as early as initial requirements phase.
Rationale
To reduce the risk surface of any solution it is wise to incorporate security criteria during design phase. This enables security and compliance criteria to be interwoven in the fabric of the solution architecture facilitating against a lower cost a desired security posture.
Implications • Security criteria must be available in the form of policies, standards and possibly guidelines • Designs must be measured against established criteria • Approval of designs must be based on security criteria also and enforced • Security criteria must be part of Scrum backlog by default • BIA and PIA must be followed by control selection

element.name: S03: Isolation (secure & resilient)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by isolating running code and security mechanisms between user sessions.
Rationale
By not sharing mechanisms like processes and threads between users attack vectors can be strongly reduced. This principle can be applied to all resources that could be used in shared fashion.
Implications • Isolate user sessions • Isolate code modules • Separate code handling unprivileged and privileged user sessions • Properly encapsulate functions in code • Limit Inter Process Communication • You can use browser supported isolation functionality for web applications to support client side isolation. • Hardening guidelines containing isolation techniques must be followed • Security Reference Architecture and code snippets must use isolation as a requirement

element.name: S06: Non Repudiation (trustworthy, vigilance)
element.documentation:
Statement
AAC must reduce risk surface by limiting deniability of actions.
Rationale
To reduce the risk surface and comply with regulations like GDPR we must make sure that we do not leak credentials easily, .e.g. not using encryption to protect credentials in transport. Legacy systems using credentials in an insecure manner can become a legal liability. Furthermore we need to ensure that actions which require non repudiation as a non-functional requirement are properly protected using authentication techniques allowed by our organisation.
Implications • Authorizations of any kind (files, users, services, customer records) in any system or process must be present to: • Guarantee non repudiation as a quality of the provided service or application • Reduce risk surface of abuse due to difficulty prosecuting offenders who demonstrate that credentials are leaked in the organisation due to lacking protection of these in one or more places. • Reduce chance of breaking separation of duty principle (See elsewhere in this list) • Logged authentication and authorisation usage is mandatory

element.name: DA08 : Data usage determines environment
element.documentation:
In our IT landscape different environments with different characteristics can be distinguished and these environments are determined according to the usage of the data.
- Based upon data usage the list of to be used environments needs to be built up.
- Separate different types of data by determining the key usage of the data. Examples are distinction between read and write architectures, focus on data integrity, etc.
Examples:
-If we for instance look at data mining we want to use big data technologies and languages as Python in combination with Tableau. The data must also be connected via metadata to enable the algoritm work. Mining direct from our source systems each having their own data represenation (syntax) can't be done.
-Another example is regarding availability, Mostly we can differentiate between direct accessability needs for events in the first six months and after. If there is no need for direct data access the data may be migrated to another technical storage gaining on costs. Last example is the GDPR data scope. This legisaltion is about the privacy of personal data. The usage and accesability of the private part of data records can be technacaliy separated when needed. The records shows than for example anominalised data whereas the private data is stored in a separate environment.

element.name: DA02 : Data is owned
element.documentation:
Each Key Data element has one data owner who is accountable for its quality.
The data originator is responsible for ensuring that the created data fulfils the data requirements, as determined by the data owner.
- Every Data owner is aware of its data usage
- A data owner is accountable for data quality
- Every data element has one owner and Data sharing agreement is established between data user and data owner
- The owner of data decides to classify data on conceptual level and if necessary on physical level
- Data Ownership resides with respective business function
- IT cannot be the owner of any business data
- GRID / Cluster / Block manager cannot be the owner of any data
- For all the Key Data Elements, respective Regional Management Team member will be the data owner
For Data elements which are not Key Data Elements will follow the following guidelines to identify the ownership:
Data Sourced externally
- Department / function which has requested the data from external sources will own the data.
- Respective regional MT member will act as the Data Owner and the person will perform the data owner role as per the definition agreed
Data Created internally
- The refers to data created for the first time or data derived or calculated using other data elements
- Business Department / Function responsible in creating the data will own the data
- For data created within the region, regional MT will be the data owner.
- For data created / derived / calculated by the Global function, will be owned by the respective GMT member

element.name: DA11 Data must have a retention period
element.documentation:
Why:
Data should be stored for purpose. At the moment their is no formal coordinated policy and way for data retention.
Rational
Data should only be stored for legal/compliance and business reasons and has an expiration date.
Impact
AACB must define the required data retention periods for the different data categories and start acting accordingly, preferable in an automated way. The retention period is part of metadata.
-Design of software should always include retention rules.
-Permanent deletion of the retained data once expired.
Use cases dec 2019
Support data owners. New regulations like GDPR in Europe. Initiatives from a.o. GTS to bring down storage costs. AACB’s transformation towards a new clearing landscape.

element.name: DA07 : Data is defined
element.documentation:
All for Business relevant data elements are linked to a business term in the ABN AMRO clearing Lexicon. Each Business term has a understandable and available definition, used consistently throughout the enterprise.
- A lexicon with aligned content on an enterprise level needs to be built up.
- The lexicon should define Business Concepts & Terms and must be managed accordingly.
- Data used within IT must have an aligned definition as defined by the Business.

element.name: DA01 : Data drives us
element.documentation:
ABN AMRO intends to use fact-based decisions to drive its business strategy, customer satisfaction and regulatory compliance. These facts are captured as data, and consequently ABN AMRO is data driven.
- Data will at least have the same amount of attention as process, system and organisation related aspects.
- For all changes within the Bank, the consequences regarding Data must always be investigated, described and validated
- ABN AMRO needs to build up an environment to facilitate advanced analytics and to produce current, accurate and integrated information, crucial for exceeding customer expectations, making decisions and meeting regulatory requirements.

element.name: DA03 : Data is secure
element.documentation:
Data is protected from unauthorised use and disclosure. This includes, but is not limited to, protection of personal, pre-decisional, and proprietary information.
- Data requires re-classification when further processing of this data (e.g. change or aggregation of data) is done.
- In order to adequately provide access to open information while maintaining secure information, security needs must be identified and developed at the data level, not the application level.
- Sensitivity labelling for access to pre-decisional, decisional, classified, sensitive, or proprietary information must be determined.
- Security must be designed into data elements from the beginning; it cannot be added later

element.name: DA04 : Data is accessible
element.documentation:
Data that is required for users to perform their tasks, shall be accessible with ease for those users , taking into account the applicable security requirements and restrictions.
- Shared data is accessed via API’s/Services (in a standardized and generic way)
- Access to Data must be granted based on Role Based Access Control mechanism.
- There is an education task to ensure that all organizations within the enterprise understand the relationship between value of data, sharing of data, and accessibility to data

element.name: DA06 : Data is exchanged using Standards
element.documentation:
Interoperability within AACB and/or with third parties is guaranteed by making use of (inter)national , industry or internal standards.
- Data exchanges between applications are based upon Enterprise standards.
- Enterprise standards are based upon Industry standards (like SWIFT, FPML) as much as possible. If this is not possible, at the least the used communication protocols must be well described and maintainable.

element.name: DA09 : Data has a Golden source
element.documentation:
The origin of the data is known and transparent, the data is always distributed or replicated from golden sources. Data is only created or changed in a golden source, followed by propagation of the update to all “controlled” copies.
- Usage of non-golden sources or uncontrolled copies must be migrated towards usage of golden sources.
- An inventory of Golden sources needs to be build up and the content needs to be accessible for everybody.
- Access to data does not necessarily grant the user access rights to modify or disclose the data. This will require an education process and a change in the organizational culture, which currently supports a belief in "ownership" of data by functional units.

element.name: DA10 : Data has Metadata
element.documentation:
For Meta-data the same rules and principles apply as for regular Data, unless explicitly stated otherwise.
- All Principles for Data also apply for meta-data
- In order to see Data in a certain context, it is described in a concerning Logical Data Model.
- This Logical Model needs to be linked to a conceptual data model, to show where Business terms are used.

element.name: DA05 : Data is shared
element.documentation:
By sharing data, efficiency is achieved by nature. Therefore, (reference and master) data is shared across enterprise functions and organisations and the data is maintained at one location only.
- Reasons why not to share data must be made explicit by the data owner
- Ensure that everybody within the enterprise understand the concept of Reference and Master data, sharing and accessibility of (master) data.
- All Reference & Master Data 2 must be assigned to one of the 3 levels (Enterprise, Shared or Non-shared)
- Governance needs to be established in order to decide on (reference and master) data (process) changes.
